sect2.title: The early years
sect2.para: Back in 1984 Apple copied the main concepts of the so called "Cambridge Ring"Cambridge RingAppleTalk's predecessor, the network technology developed mainly by Andy Hopper for AcornAcornDeveloped AppleTalk basics together with the University of Cambridge.

Different machines were interconnected via daisy-chaining in a bus topology with a maximum speed of 230 Kbps. From a today's point of view a very slow implementation. FarallonFarallonOne of the early AppleTalk adopters developed an alternative to the classic LocalTalk cabling, called PhoneNetPhoneNetLocalTalk cabling alternative in the early days which allowed a star topology via Hubs, too.

Later, additional physical layers have been added like Ethernet/IEEE 802.3 (EtherTalk)EtherTalkAppleTalk on Ethernet or IEEE 802.3 hardware, FDDIFDDIFiber distributed data interface (FDDITalk)FDDITalkAppleTalk on FDDI hardware, TokenRingTokenRingNetwork Technology developed by IBM (TokenTalk)TokenTalkAppleTalk on TokenRing hardware or using the Infrared port (IRTalk)IRTalkAppleTalk over Infrared.

sect2.title: Naming conventions change
sect2.para: To be able to differentiate between the different physical transport layers, Apple changed the naming conventions. What has been known as "AppleTalk" before, is called "LocalTalk" from then on. "AppleTalk" itself is a synonym for Apple's networking techniques in general, including several underlying physical layers (see above) up to higher-level protocols that provide file and print services (see below)

sect2.title: LocalTalk's heritage
sect2.para: Due to the slow transmission speed of the original AppleTalk implementation, a packet sizePacket sizemaximum size of an AppleTalk packet of maximum 586 bytes has been chosen. This small packet size has been adopted to the other physical layers as well (making it possible to route AppleTalk packets via routers between segments using different physical media transparently).

What has been a good compromise for LocalTalk turned into one main disadvantage of AppleTalk on other physical media: The inability to use the underlying network characteristics in an efficient way (an Ethernet frame is 1500 bytes large, for example)

With the increase of physical transfer speed (100 Mbps with "Fast Ethernet" for example) the need for alternatives grew more and more. Apple decided to add different transportation layers for file services (Apple Filing Protocol). In the mid 90s they developed a generic "Data Stream Interface" (DSI) as an abstraction layer to be able to use AppleTalk over more efficient protocols like TCP.

For most of their customers nothing changed, because the Apple engineers integrated the ability to automagically switch between AppleTalk and TCP. People still used the chooser and AppleTalk to connect to the server but in case, both client and server were able to "speak" AFP over TCP, they changed the protocol without notifying the user.
